channel.title: Hyperion plugin system (Think of bukkit)
channel.description:
So, let's make it clear that i am not a very good programmer and i'm not even sure if i'm gonna keep developing this. Just want to see some feedback on it and ask if you guys see any use in plugins for Hyperion.
What it does so far is load the standard 317 Hyperion server and loads all jar files in a specific folder. Then it executes run() on every jar loaded.
[img]http://img51.imageshack.us/img51/2886/hizm.png[/img][img]http://img11.imageshack.us/img11/2431/4ufj.png[/img]
Future plans? add a config files to allow users to choose the main plugin class (it's hardcoded atm :/), obviously much much more hooks and an API.
Feedback appreciated but keep in mind what i said on the first lines.

item.title: Hyperion plugin system (Think of bukkit)
item.dc:creator: @whattehp406 whattehp406
item.description:
@whattehp406 wrote:

[quote=“blackflag_, post:23, topic:533975”][quote author=whattehp406 link=topic=652772.msg4375052#msg4375052 date=1381844825]
I just don’t see why everyone works separate. Why don’t we all work on one great source that has no (or hardly any) bugs. Implement a plugin/scripting system that works properly and instead of making new sources and 1000 tutorials on how to do a command just make plugins.
[/quote]
http://www.moparisthebest.com/smf/index.php?topic=526031.0[/quote]Hadn’t seen that yet, thank you.

Read full topic

item.title: Hyperion plugin system (Think of bukkit)
item.dc:creator: @davidi2 Davidi2
item.description:
@davidi2 wrote:

[quote=“sinisoul, post:20, topic:533975”][quote author=Davidi2 link=topic=652772.msg4374582#msg4374582 date=1381709148]

Same goes for Apollo’s JRuby implementation, if I took it and implemented it into a Hyperion it wouldn’t work either, same for the plugins written for it. The bootstrap would have to be written to fit Hyperion’s source.
[/quote]Yup that’s what I was saying. Although technically you’d have to rewrite the scriptcontext more than the bootstrap

Im just going to note however that the scripting system for that is pretty flexible and it wouldnt be hard to implement.[/quote]Yes, but what the person calling me out said was that you wouldn’t have to change anything for the scripting system for it to work on other sources (or rather, what I said and he called me out for). I know what I said was somewhat unrelated (because it has nothing to do with the actual revision), and maybe that’s what the guy was talking about, I was just trying to point out it wouldn’t work for most bases without some modification.

Read full topic

item.title: Hyperion plugin system (Think of bukkit)
item.dc:creator: @sinisoul sini
item.description:
@sinisoul wrote:

[quote=“Davidi2, post:18, topic:533975”][quote author=AtomicInt_ link=topic=652772.msg4374580#msg4374580 date=1381708558]
Same goes for Apollo’s JRuby implementation, if I took it and implemented it into a Hyperion it wouldn’t work either, same for the plugins written for it. The bootstrap would have to be written to fit Hyperion’s source.
[/quote]Yup that’s what I was saying. Although technically you’d have to rewrite the scriptcontext more than the bootstrap[/quote]

Im just going to note however that the scripting system for that is pretty flexible and it wouldnt be hard to implement.

item.title: Hyperion plugin system (Think of bukkit)
item.dc:creator: @ExtremeX-Scape Ryley
item.description:
@ExtremeX-Scape wrote:

While you have a point, the system was written for Hyperion; regardless of Java not being very dynamic you shouldn’t expect someone to just take all of the prewritten plugins and the system and add it to their base (different from Hyperion obv.) Same goes for Apollo’s JRuby implementation, if I took it and implemented it into a Hyperion it wouldn’t work either, same for the plugins written for it. The bootstrap would have to be written to fit Hyperion’s source.

Read full topic

item.title: Hyperion plugin system (Think of bukkit)
item.dc:creator: @whattehp406 whattehp406
item.description:
@whattehp406 wrote:

The only way this would be very very useful is when people just use hyperion and the community starts working together to create plugins instead of everyone secretly trying to make a seperate base. We gotta work together, it’s much more efficient.

Read full topic

item.title: Hyperion plugin system (Think of bukkit)
item.dc:creator: @davidi2 Davidi2
item.description:
@davidi2 wrote:

[quote=“King JC, post:14, topic:533975”]@David, just like in the same way you have to accommodate for IE, Chrome, FireFox etc. in web design to make your page compatible with all browsers?[/quote]ehhhh, not really quite the same… think of it more like if all PHP methods had to be implemented differently for each browser… for the end-user programmer it would look really nice, but the developer would have to create a new set of hooks and such for each browser… and you couldnt use php unless it had been written for that browser. Now imagine that but for the lots of different sources out there here

Read full topic

item.title: Hyperion plugin system (Think of bukkit)
item.dc:creator: @davidi2 Davidi2
item.description:
@davidi2 wrote:

[quote=“Wizard jesse, post:6, topic:534035”][quote author=Davidi2 link=topic=652772.msg4374239#msg4374239 date=1381606986]
Problem with a java plugin system like this is that it is not very dynamic at all when it comes to working with multiple sources. So yes, using a 474 IS a problem if it’s not hyperion. You could have a great plugin system that works with hyperion and that doesnt work at all with any other source because of the design pattern and such.
[/quote]

how did you get java guru?

also im done with posting since it seems to be mostly a big mess in here…[/quote]let me spell it out for you

let’s say you created a Hyperion plugin system. you would have a whole API that calls the different Hyperion methods through your plugin system… for example

package plugin.hyperion; class PlayerMethodProvider { //sendMessage and shit like that based on Hyperion methods }
If you were to use a different source, NONE of those would work, and you’d essentially have to rewrite most of the plugin system again because Java is not that dynamic. When you look at a plugin system for something else, like minecraft, they don’t have to change their methods very often because the game methods don’t change drastically at all, they just have to find the hooks in the server/client and tie those back into the already existing methods…

So technically its feasible to have a plugin system that works with multiple sources, but every source would need its own adaptation of the method providers. IE - the plugin system the OP is writing would NOT work for any other source than Hyperion out of the box.

Read full topic

item.dc:creator: @Clawz_fury lare69
item.description:
@Clawz_fury wrote:

[quote=“Wizard jesse, post:6, topic:534035”][quote author=Davidi2 link=topic=652772.msg4374239#msg4374239 date=1381606986]
Problem with a java plugin system like this is that it is not very dynamic at all when it comes to working with multiple sources. So yes, using a 474 IS a problem if it’s not hyperion. You could have a great plugin system that works with hyperion and that doesnt work at all with any other source because of the design pattern and such.
[/quote]

how did you get java guru?

also im done with posting since it seems to be mostly a big mess in here…[/quote]
what he said makes perfect sense although if the plugin system isn’t adaptable on many bases it really isn’t a good plugin system.

Read full topic
